What a bunch of bullsh!t, this whole idea of evolution is scientifically impossible!  There’s no possible way to get DNA into a cell to create life!  There’s no possible way that DNA can form on its own, you can dream up all the theories you want, but there’s no possible way that DNA can spontaneously generate into existence!  That’s why these dumb ass scientists have no clue about how the nucleus came to be!  DNA is information, and information can only come from an intelligent source!  Seriously, do you really believe that DNA, the code of life, just formed completely by chance?  A few million base pairs magically linked up in the correct sequence to create and regulate life?  Somehow this unique cell is programmed to reproduce itself, and starts making copies of itself and keeps dividing for the next 4.5 billion years?  During this time, random genetic mutations will make the cell “evolve” into every species of organisms that have ever existed?  That has to be the most preposterous idea I’ve ever heard!  The notion of each Kingdom in Biology “evolving” from a single celled bacteria is beyond fantasy!  Then having each Phylum “evolve” into existence, the Order, then the Classes, Families, Genus, and each Species “evolving”?  How could anyone ever believe that this is how life came to be?

It does make sense that if our ancestors had protein-assembling machinery both inside and outside the nucleus, one or the other set would atrophy and disappear as the other becomes dominant. Maybe which of the two won out could have come down to mRNA being the least energy-intensive thing to transport across the nuclear membrane, as opposed to DNA ior assembled proteins?

The macrovirus hypothesis is presented in this video as an alternative to the inside-out hypothesis, but also suggests a very modest extension of the inside-out hypothesis to explain the same thing. It might plausibly be that minimising activity which goes on inside the nucleus helps to optimise its function as a safe nonvolatile storage area. On another hand, perhaps it could be that a macrovirus got blebbed up at some point along with the ancestors of mitochondria, chloroplasts, and such.

If our whole Eukaryote lineage might include not only endosymbiosis between multiple prokaryotes, but also virus particles, personally we find that notion rather warm and fuzzy rather than disturbing: an extension of the endosymbiote hypothesis, wherein some of our ancestors tried to eat other ancestors of ours, but instead they survived together and their descendants are different parts of our cells today.

Venturing beyond modest speculation and into the very wild, so take with a big grain of salt, perhaps today's macroviruses might instead be descendants of Eukaryote nuclei: occasionally ribosomes get into the nucleus, and over a lot of die rolls, one led to a replicating nucleus. Similar throwbacks on a much larger size scale are occasionally successful, including "immortal lines" of animal cells behaving like protists, so a naturally-ocurring rogue nucleus behaving like a virus is at the very least plausible enough for reasonably hard sci fi.

I still like Lynn Margulis' endosymbiotic theory for the origin of chloroplasts, mitochondria, and nuclei. It appears to me, though, that the nucleus originated as an archaean endoparasite. After being gobbled up by the host "bug" the incipient nucleus took command of the host. The host shed its DNA while retaining its protein-making machinery, and the boss parasite (nucleus) shed its protein-making machinery while retaining its DNA.

If I had to guess, I'd think a cell would fold in on itself in the manner explained in invagination to increase surface area as an evolutionary adaptation to cells becoming larger. A larger cell will have less surface area compared to its volume, but if the cell's outer membrane folds in on itself, the cell has a lot more surface area to exchange various chemicals and nutrients with its environment, and better sustain itself. I'd wager this is how vacuoles came to be in cells as well. But I don't know if vacuoles have a double membrane or not. Which would lend credence to this theory.

It is pretty clear that plants' chloroplasts were originally a free-floating cyanobacteria relative that got absorbed by a fungal cell who realized, "This guy dumps sugar!  I'm keeping him." Over time several of the from the chloroplasts got moved into the nucleus and now the plant cell controls the timing of chloroplasts' reproduction and other activities; the DNA in the chloroplast just makes the protein to maintain the organelle and turn red and blue light into sugars.  Genetic sequencing has done a lot is showing how the plant cell controls its chloroplasts.  If we could identify which specialist bacteria had relatives that became mitochondria, we could use similar genetic sequencing to determine the modern relationships between the cell and its organelles.

For reference there is a but of additional research in support of the Viral Eukaryogenesis hypothesis particularly phylogenetic seems to show that the conserved Nuclear Genome shares a common ancestor with the conserved genome of the Nucleocytoviricota the viral family of Nucleocytoplasmic large DNA Viruses. The tricky bit is that this can be argued both ways regarding which came first was the original nucleolus a virus or did an original cell go onto found a lineage of viruses?

Additionally the proteins used to construct the Nucleolus double membrane, endoplasmic reticulum histones, and the cytoskeleton have thus far only been found within the viral group and Eukaryotes. Neither have been found within Prokaryotes in either Archaea or Bacteria thus far only within giant viruses where they play vital roles in high jacking the cells ribosomes and or the packaging of viral material into protein shells. It also should be noted that both bacteria and archaea use circular genomes whereas DNA viruses and eukaryotes use linear genomes which is interesting.

One thing with some of the giant viruses is that they appear to be able to infect any type of Eukaryotic cell, amoebozoans, ciliates, various algae, fungi if it swallows the virus capsule via phagocytosis it is fair game. It seems likely this has to do with the viruses not using the transcription machinery of their hosts due to having their own so they only need the hosts ribosomes to actually translate the contents. That gives an evolutionary advantage for greater autonomy for a virus as if it can infect a wider array of hosts, then the more easily it can spread.

Giant viruses are pretty terrifying in that regard. The other eerie bit is that one of the deadly scourges of humanity thus far the only one ever gotten rid of small box is a member of this viral family like all pox viruses it is a reduced member of the Nucleocytoviricota in terms of the size of its genome. Herpes viruses are also members of this larger clade. So yes this means we in some real sense share a common ancestor with small pox herpes and other DNA viruses....

I'm rather more impressed with how Nick Lane wrote about it.  Basically an Archaeal methanogen lived in an environment with Bacteria that produced hydrogen as a respiratory by product.  As the archaea needed as much hydrogen as possible it wrapped itself around the bacterium to insure it got all that the bacterium could produce.  After several generations of bacterium dying and leaving behind DNA some of it got included into the archaea's DNA.  Some of this DNA included genes for bacterial membranes, but not the instructions for what part of the cell they were supposed to function in so they globed around and formed the first nucleus.  And to cut a long story short it was preserved because it gave RNA strands time to get fixed because the rain of bacterial genes that were being incorporated into the proto-nucleus were making a giant mess of things.

We keep thinking about things as complete, HEALTHY organisms.  What if a DEFECTIVE giant virus infected a prokaryote cell but could not take over, so it just stayed in there in its own pocket trying to do its thing and failing, but providing such things as protection from OTHER invaders?  This would make having the defective virus a benefit ("Dead men tell no tales" in reverse) and if the cell itself when it replicated could provide the virus what it needed to replicate too, then the pair would keep going and adding new things, as it was more durable than the plain prokaryote cells nearby and lasted essentially forever, allowing it to eventually have all sorts of things change in it.  And the rest is history...

I find it weird that there is no evolutional hypothesis on how such a virus could become a nucleus. Because to me it sounds pretty simple. The giant virus is very big. It likely thats a lot of time and energy to produce more, so the virus sets up shop in the cell for some time. That in turn means, the longer the infected cell survives the better for this type of virus. That would cause evolutionary pressure towards basically coinhabitating the cell and turning from an infection into a full on parasite. And that is not to far from the Virus ending up in the cell alone and taking over fully.

You make a fundamental mistake : you say the a virus "makes".
A virus doesn't make anything because it is lifeless. It is not like a bacteria which has an individual metabolism on its own.
The virus is just a very small piece of genetic material with no metabolism at all that is multiplied by a cell's own mecanism.
Left outside on a surface a virus disintegrates in a few hours.
In contrast, a bacteria survives because it has its own independent metabolism.
So agent Smith is right. Humans are a virus. ;)

What if the mitochondria or giant viruses created the evolutionary pressure to having a nucleus? It does protect the DNA from a lot of effects. But to a degree that makes it unsuiteable as the primary outer hull of cells.
It is propable that mitchondria or viruses (or their predecessors) could damage the host cells DNA, unless it is protected by a nucleus.
Once you got a fitting evolutionary pressure, even seemingly negative random mutations can become a survival trait. Just think about any of the blood diseases that limit the spread of Malaria: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_genetic_resistance_to_malaria
By every definition, those are genetical illnesses. But as there is a Evolutionary pressure that makes them usefull, they are actually noticeably more common in populations affected by malaria.
It could even be that the giant virus evolved from nucelei. They are a wierd intermediate step, where they do still need a outside cell to reproduce but also carry some of the machinery.

The bleb hypothesis does explain why there are no ribosomes in the nucleus, it would have been clearer if you gave a more detailed model of the cell. The retuculum is a closed membrane that is separate from the outer membrane, and inside the lumen of the reticulum the conditions are basically in continuation with the outside enviroment. Archea's ribosomes are found in the cytoplasm and to work they stick to the membrane, pumping the newly made proteins outside the cell if necessary. This machinery specialized to stick only to the cell-side of the reticulum since we don't see ribosomes sticking to the outer membrane of the cell.

The nucleus itself isn't inside the lumen of the reticulum, it's a region of the cytoplasm that is partially enclosed with lumen, but there are numerous "pores" where it directly communicates with the cytoplasm, so theye are no ribosomes inside the nucleus for the same reason there are no ribosomes on the outer membrane: there's no reason to.
